q.s:
Complete the bass line for the melody below, following eighteenth-century voice-leading procedures. Below the bass line, write the Roman and Arabic numerals that indicate the harmonies and inversions implied by the soprano and bass.

Observe the following:

  1. Keep the portion you compose consistent with the first phrase.

    1. Write an appropriate cadence at each phrase ending.

    2. Give melodic interest to the bass line. (Nonharmonic tones, if included, should be limited to unaccented passing and neighbor tones.)

    3. Vary the motion of the bass line in relation to the soprano.

    4. Use mostly quarter notes. (Where appropriate, note values ranging from half notes to eighth notes may be used.)

  2. Do not notate alto and tenor lines.

Enter any notes as you prepare your response.

q.s:
Look over the melody and begin practicing. You have 75 seconds to practice. This is the starting pitch of the printed melody.

Press record to begin your performance.

f.c:
Assignment: For the given melody, sing the pitches in accurate rhythm and with a steady tempo.

Procedure: You will have 75 seconds to practice and 30 seconds to perform the melody. You will hear the starting pitch at the beginning of the 75-second practice period. After the end of the practice period, you will have 30 seconds to perform the melody. A recorded announcement will alert you to the end of each practice and performance period. Directions on the recording will assist you in operating the recorder.

Your performance:

  1. You may sing note names (C-D-E), syllable names (do-re-mi), scale-degree numbers (1-2-3), or a neutral syllable (for example, ta-ta-ta).

  2. Even though you will hear the starting pitch of the printed melody, you may transpose the melody to a key that is comfortable.

  3. You should use some of the practice time to perform out loud. You may write on the music if you wish.

  4. You may not use any device (for example, a metronome or a musical instrument) to assist you in your practice or performance.

  5. You will be evaluated on rhythmic accuracy, pitch accuracy (relative to tonic), and continuity (maintaining a steady tempo). You may start over if you need to, but there will be a deduction from your score. You will not be evaluated on the quality of your singing voice.

q.s:
Complete the bass line for the melody below, making sure to keep the portion you compose consistent with the first phrase. Place Roman numerals with inversion symbols below the bass line to indicate the harmonies implied by the soprano and bass.

Observe the following.

  1. Your bass line should make melodic sense in relation to the given soprano line.

    1. Give melodic interest to the bass line.

    2. Vary the motion of the bass line in relation to the soprano.

    3. Use mostly quarter notes, but you may use note values ranging from half notes to eighth notes.

  2. Your bass line and chord choices should make harmonic sense with the melody.

    1. Use an appropriate cadence at each phrase ending.

    2. Use at least two chords or two positions of the same chord per measure.

  3. Do not notate alto and tenor lines.

Enter any notes as you prepare your response.

q.s:
Look over the melody and begin practicing. You have 75 seconds to practice. This is the starting pitch of the printed melody.

Press record to begin your performance.

f.c:
Assignment: For the given melody, sing the pitches in accurate rhythm and with a steady tempo.

Procedure: You will have 75 seconds to practice and 30 seconds to perform the melody. You will hear the starting pitch at the beginning of the 75-second practice period. After the end of the practice period, you will have 30 seconds to perform the melody. A recorded announcement will alert you to the end of each practice and performance period. Directions on the recording will assist you in operating the recorder.

Your performance:

(a) You may sing note names (c-d-e), syllable names (do-re-mi), scale-degree numbers (1-2-3), or a neutral syllable (for example, ta-ta-ta).

(b) Even though you will hear the starting pitch of the printed melody, you may transpose the melody to a key that is comfortable.

(c) You should use some of the warm-up and practice time to perform out loud. You may write on the music if you wish.

(d) You may not use any device (for example, a metronome or a musical instrument) to assist you in your practice or performance.

(e) You will be evaluated on pitch accuracy (relative to tonic), rhythm, and continuity (maintaining a steady tempo). You may start over if you need to, but there will be a deduction from your score. You will not be evaluated on the quality of your singing voice.

q.s:
Complete the bass line for the melody below. Your bass line should make both melodic and harmonic sense in common practice style and should remain consistent with the given first phrase. Show your harmonization of the melody by placing Roman numerals with inversion symbols under your bass line. Do not notate an alto or tenor line.

Observe the following in composing the bass line and in making chord choices:

  1. Give melodic interest to the bass line.

  2. Vary the motion of the bass line in relation to the soprano.

  3. Use an appropriate cadence at each phrase ending.

  4. Use at least two chords or two positions of the same chord per measure.

  5. Note values ranging from half notes to eighth notes are permitted.

Skill:Skill 4.A: Apply knowledge of common-practice tonality to spell chords and to follow procedures of 18th-century voice leading to connect chords in harmonic progressions.
Skill:Skill 4.D: Compose a bass line to harmonize a given melody, implying appropriate harmony, and identify the implied harmony using Roman and Arabic numerals.
Question Type:FRQ: Harmonization of a Melody

q.s:
Look over the melody and begin practicing. You have 75 seconds to practice. This is the starting pitch of the printed melody.

You will have 30 seconds to perform the melody.

f.c:
Assignment: For each of the two given melodies, sing the pitches in accurate rhythm and with a steady tempo.

Procedure: You will have 75 seconds to warm up and practice. You will have 30 seconds to perform the melody. A recorded announcement will alert you to the end of each practice and performance period. Directions on the recording will assist you in operating the recorder.

Your Performance:

  1. You may sing note names (c-d-e), syllable names (do-re-mi), scale-degree numbers (1-2-3), or a neutral syllable (for example, ta-ta-ta).

  2. Even though you will hear the starting pitch of the printed melody, you may transpose the melody to a register that is comfortable.

  3. You should use some of the warm-up and practice time to perform out loud. You may write on the music if you wish.

  4. You may not use any device (for example, a metronome or a musical instrument) to assist you in your practice or performance.

  5. You will be evaluated on pitch accuracy (relative to tonic), rhythm, and continuity (maintaining a steady tempo). You may start over if you need to, but there will be a deduction from your score. You will not be evaluated on the quality of your singing voice.

q.s:
Before listening to the first playing, please look at the staff below. Notice that there are nine chords in the progression; the soprano and bass notes and the Roman numeral of the first chord are given.

Now listen to the progression for the first time and begin working.

f.c:
You will hear a harmonic progression in four parts. In each case, the progression will be played four times. There will be a pause of 30 seconds after the first playing and a 1-minute pause after each subsequent playing. The pulse will be established before the first playing. For each question, please do the following.

  1. Notate only the soprano and bass voices. Do not notate the alto and tenor voices.

  2. On the lines provided under each staff, write in the Roman and Arabic numerals that indicate the chords and their inversions.

tg: Skill Category:Skill Category 3: Apply conventions of musical notation and performance in converting music between aural and written forms.
Topic:4.3: Harmonic Progression, Functional Harmony, and Cadences
Skill:Skill 3.B: Notate the soprano and bass pitches of a performed harmonic progression in a major or minor key (may include chromatically altered pitches).
Skill:Skill 3.C: Identify the harmonic function of chords in a performed harmonic progression by providing an analysis using Roman and Arabic numerals.

q.s:
Before listening to the progression for the first time, please look at the staff below. Notice that there are eleven chords in the progression; the soprano and bass notes and the Roman numeral of the first chord are given.

Remember to notate only the soprano and bass voices and to provide the numerals indicating the chords and their inversions. Now listen to the progression for the first time and begin working.

f.c:
You will hear a harmonic progression in four parts. In each case, the progression will be played four times. There will be a pause of 30 seconds after the first playing and a 1-minute pause after each subsequent playing. The pulse will be established before the first playing. For each question, please do the following.

  1. Notate only the soprano and bass voices. Do not notate the alto and tenor voices.

  2. On the lines provided under each staff, write in the Roman and Arabic numerals that indicate the chords and their inversions.

tg: Skill Category:Skill Category 3: Apply conventions of musical notation and performance in converting music between aural and written forms.
Topic:4.3: Harmonic Progression, Functional Harmony, and Cadences
Skill:Skill 3.B: Notate the soprano and bass pitches of a performed harmonic progression in a major or minor key (may include chromatically altered pitches).
Skill:Skill 3.C: Identify the harmonic function of chords in a performed harmonic progression by providing an analysis using Roman and Arabic numerals.

q.s: Realize the figured bass below in four voices, following traditional eighteenth-century voice-leading procedures. Continue logically from the spacing of the first chord. In the space below each chord, supply the Roman numeral that appropriately indicates harmonic function.
tg: Skill Category:Skill Category 4: Complete music based on cues, following 18th-century stylistic norms.
Skill:Skill 4.A: Apply knowledge of common-practice tonality to spell chords and to follow procedures of 18th-century voice leading to connect chords in harmonic progressions.
Skill:Skill 4.B: Complete a four-part harmonic progression by realizing a figured bass line and providing a Roman numeral analysis of the completed progression.
Question Type:FRQ: Part Writing from Figured Bass

q.s:
Directions: Suggested time - 20 minutes.

Complete the bass line for the melody below. Your bass line should make both melodic and harmonic sense in common practice style and should remain consistent with the given first phrase. Show your harmonization of the melody by placing Roman numerals with inversion symbols under your bass line. (Do NOT notate an alto or tenor line.)

Observe the following in composing the bass line and in making chord choices.

  1. Give melodic interest to the bass line by balancing conjunct and disjunct motion, providing shape and direction, and covering an ample range.

  2. Vary the motion of the bass line in relation to the soprano, employing some contrary motion.

  3. Use an appropriate cadence at each phrase ending.

  4. Use at least two chords or two positions of the same chord per measure except for the last measure.

  5. Appropriate use of inversions and seventh chords is permitted.

  6. Note values ranging from eighth to half notes are permitted; a whole note may be used in the last measure.
tg: Skill Category:Skill Category 4: Complete music based on cues, following 18th-century stylistic norms.
Skill:Skill 4.A: Apply knowledge of common-practice tonality to spell chords and to follow procedures of 18th-century voice leading to connect chords in harmonic progressions.
Skill:Skill 4.D: Compose a bass line to harmonize a given melody, implying appropriate harmony, and identify the implied harmony using Roman and Arabic numerals.
Question Type:FRQ: Harmonization of a Melody

q.s:
Look over the melody and begin practicing. You have 75 seconds to practice. This is the starting pitch of the printed melody.

Press record to begin your performance.

f.c:
Assignment: For each of the two given melodies, sing the pitches in accurate rhythm and with a steady tempo.

Procedure: You will hear the starting pitch at the beginning of the practice period. You will have 75 seconds to warm up and practice. After hearing the starting pitch again, you will have 30 seconds to perform the melody. A recorded announcement will alert you to the end of each practice and performance period. Directions on the recording will assist you in operating the recorder.

Your Performance:

  1. You may sing note names (c-d-e), syllable names (do-re-mi), scale-degree numbers (1-2-3), or a neutral syllable (for example, ta-ta-ta).

  2. Even though you will hear the starting pitch of the printed melody, you may transpose the melody to a register that is comfortable.

  3. You should use some of the warm-up and practice time to perform out loud. You may write on the music if you wish.

  4. You may not use any device (for example, a metronome or a musical instrument) to assist you in your practice or performance.

  5. You will be evaluated on pitch accuracy (relative to tonic), rhythm, and continuity (maintaining a steady tempo). You may start over if you need to, but there will be a deduction from your score. You will not be evaluated on the quality of your singing voice.

tg: Skill Category:Skill Category 3: Apply conventions of musical notation and performance in converting music between aural and written forms.

Skill:Skill 3.D: Apply knowledge of musical symbols and terms to sing the pitches and rhythms of a notated melody (melody may be in treble or bass clef, in a major or minor key, or in simple or compound meter, and it may include chromatically altered pitches).

  2. Even though you will hear the starting pitch of the printed melody, you may transpose the melody to a register that is comfortable.

  3. You should use some of the warm-up and practice time to perform out loud. You may write on the music if you wish.

  4. You may not use any device (for example, a metronome, a musical instrument) to assist you in your practice or performance.

  5. You will be evaluated on pitch accuracy (relative to tonic), rhythm, and continuity (maintaining a steady tempo). You may start over, if you need to, but there will be a deduction from your score. You will not be evaluated on the quality of your singing voice.

q.s:
The melody will be played three times. There will be a pause of 30 seconds after the first playing and a one-minute pause after each subsequent playing. There are no rests in the melody you will hear. It will be played on a violin.

Now listen to the melody for the first time and begin to notate it.

f.c: You are to notate on the staves provided the correct pitch and rhythm of a short melody that you will hear. Make sure that any accidentals you use are appropriate for the key signature provided. The pulse will be established before the first playing of the melody.

tg: Skill Category:Skill Category 3: Apply conventions of musical notation and performance in converting music between aural and written forms.
Skill:Skill 3.A: Notate the pitches and rhythm of a performed melody (in treble or bass clef; in a major or minor key; may include chromatically altered pitches).

q.s:
The melody will be played four times. There will be a pause of 30 seconds after the first playing and a one-minute pause after each subsequent playing. There are no rests in the melody you will hear. It will be played on a bassoon.

The pitch of the first note has been provided. Be sure to notate the rhythm of that note. Now listen to the melody for the first time and begin to notate it.

f.c: You are to notate on the staves provided the correct pitch and rhythm of a short melody that you will hear. Make sure that any accidentals you use are appropriate for the key signature provided. The pulse will be established before the first playing of the melody.

tg: Skill Category:Skill Category 3: Apply conventions of musical notation and performance in converting music between aural and written forms.
Skill:Skill 3.A: Notate the pitches and rhythm of a performed melody (in treble or bass clef; in a major or minor key; may include chromatically altered pitches).

q.s:
Before listening to the first playing, please look at the staff below. Notice that there are nine chords in the progression; the soprano and bass notes and the Roman numeral of the first chord are given.

q.s:
Look over the melody and begin practicing. You have 75 seconds to practice. This is the starting pitch of the printed melody.

Press record to begin your performance.

f.c:
Assignment: For each of the two given melodies, sing the pitches in accurate rhythm and with a steady tempo.

Procedure: For each melody, you will have 75 seconds to practice and 30 seconds to perform the melody. You will hear the starting pitch for each melody at the beginning of the 75-second practice period. After the end of the practice period, you will have 30 seconds to perform the melody. A recorded announcement will alert you to the end of each practice and performance period. Directions on the recording will assist you in operating the recorder.

Your performance:

  1. You may sing note names (C-D-E), syllable names (do-re-mi), scale-degree numbers (1-2-3), or a neutral syllable (for example, ta-ta-ta).

  2. Even though you will hear the starting pitch of the printed melody, you may transpose the melody to a key that is comfortable.

  3. You should use some of the practice time to perform out loud. You may write on the music if you wish.

  4. You may not use any device (for example, a metronome or a musical instrument) to assist you in your practice or performance.

  5. You will be evaluated on rhythmic accuracy, pitch accuracy (relative to tonic), and continuity (maintaining a steady tempo). You may start over if you need to, but there will be a deduction from your score. You will not be evaluated on the quality of your singing voice.

Notate on the staff provided the correct pitch and rhythm of a short melody that you will hear. Make sure that any accidentals you use are appropriate for the key signature provided. The pulse will be established before the melody is played. The melody you will hear uses all of the measures provided below and contains no rests.

The pitch of the first note has been provided. Be sure to notate the rhythm of that note. Now listen to the melody for the first time and begin working.

Suggested time: Play the melody four times, with a pause of 30 seconds after the first playing and a pause of 1 minute after each subsequent playing.

q.s:
Assignment: Sing the pitches in accurate rhythm and with a steady tempo.

Procedure: You should use 1 minute and 15 seconds to practice and up to 30 seconds to perform the melody. You may play the starting pitch for the melody at the beginning of the practice period.

Your performance:

  • 1. You may sing note names (C-D-E), syllable names (do-re-mi), scale-degree numbers (1-2-3), or a neutral syllable (for example, ta-ta-ta).
  • 2. Even though you will hear the starting pitch of the printed melody, you may transpose the melody to a key that is comfortable.
  • 3. You should use some of the practice time to perform out loud. You may write on the music if you wish.
  • 4. You may not use any device (for example, a metronome or a musical instrument) to assist you in your practice or performance.
  • 5. You will be evaluated on rhythmic accuracy, pitch accuracy (relative to tonic), and continuity (maintaining a steady tempo). You may start over, if you need to, but there will be a deduction from your score. You will not be evaluated on the quality of your singing voice.

Look over the melody, practice the melody, and then perform the melody.

Suggested time: Play the starting pitch for the melody and then use 1 minute and 15 seconds to practice and up to 30 seconds to perform the melody.

Notate on the staff provided the correct pitch and rhythm of a short melody that you will hear. Make sure that any accidentals you use are appropriate for the key signature provided. The pulse will be established before the melody is played. The melody you will hear uses all of the measures provided below and contains no rests.

The pitch of the first note has been provided. Be sure to notate the rhythm of that note. Now listen to the melody for the first time and begin working.

Suggested time: Play the melody four times, with a pause of 30 seconds after the first playing and a pause of 1 minute after each subsequent playing.
tg: Skill Category:Skill Category 3: Apply conventions of musical notation and performance in converting music between aural and written forms.

Topic:1.5: Major Keys and Key Signatures

q.s:
Assignment: Sing the pitches in accurate rhythm and with a steady tempo.

Procedure: You should use 1 minute and 15 seconds to practice and up to 30 seconds to perform the melody. You may play the starting pitch for the melody at the beginning of the practice period.

Your performance:

  • 1. You may sing note names (C-D-E), syllable names (do-re-mi), scale-degree numbers (1-2-3), or a neutral syllable (for example, ta-ta-ta).
  • 2. Even though you will hear the starting pitch of the printed melody, you may transpose the melody to a key that is comfortable.
  • 3. You should use some of the practice time to perform out loud. You may write on the music if you wish.
  • 4. You may not use any device (for example, a metronome or a musical instrument) to assist you in your practice or performance.
  • 5. You will be evaluated on rhythmic accuracy, pitch accuracy (relative to tonic), and continuity (maintaining a steady tempo). You may start over, if you need to, but there will be a deduction from your score. You will not be evaluated on the quality of your singing voice.

Look over the melody, practice the melody, and then perform the melody.

Suggested time: Play the starting pitch for the melody and then use 1 minute and 15 seconds to practice and up to 30 seconds to perform the melody.

q.s:
Assignment: Sing the pitches in accurate rhythm and with a steady tempo.

Procedure: You should use 1 minute and 15 seconds to practice and up to 30 seconds to perform the melody. You may play the starting pitch for the melody at the beginning of the practice period.

Your performance:

  • 1. You may sing note names (C-D-E), syllable names (do-re-mi), scale-degree numbers (1-2-3), or a neutral syllable (for example, ta-ta-ta).

    2. Even though you will hear the starting pitch of the printed melody, you may transpose the melody to a key that is comfortable.

    3. You should use some of the practice time to perform out loud. You may write on the music if you wish.

    4. You may not use any device (for example, a metronome or a musical instrument) to assist you in your practice or performance.

    5. You will be evaluated on rhythmic accuracy, pitch accuracy (relative to tonic), and continuity (maintaining a steady tempo). You may start over, if you need to, but there will be a deduction from your score. You will not be evaluated on the quality of your singing voice.

Look over the melody, practice the melody, and then perform the melody.

Suggested time: Play the starting pitch for the melody and then use 1 minute and 15 seconds to practice and up to 30 seconds to perform the melody.

q.s:
Assignment: Sing the pitches in accurate rhythm and with a steady tempo.

Procedure: You should use 1 minute and 15 seconds to practice and up to 30 seconds to perform the melody. You may play the starting pitch for the melody at the beginning of the practice period.

Your performance:

  • 1. You may sing note names (C-D-E), syllable names (do-re-mi), scale-degree numbers (1-2-3), or a neutral syllable (for example, ta-ta-ta).
  • 2. Even though you will hear the starting pitch of the printed melody, you may transpose the melody to a key that is comfortable.
  • 3. You should use some of the practice time to perform out loud. You may write on the music if you wish.
  • 4. You may not use any device (for example, a metronome or a musical instrument) to assist you in your practice or performance.
  • 5. You will be evaluated on rhythmic accuracy, pitch accuracy (relative to tonic), and continuity (maintaining a steady tempo). You may start over, if you need to, but there will be a deduction from your score. You will not be evaluated on the quality of your singing voice.

Look over the melody, practice the melody, and then perform the melody.

Suggested time: Play the starting pitch for the melody and then use 1 minute and 15 seconds to practice and up to 30 seconds to perform the melody.

  • 3. On the blanks provided under the staff, write the Roman and Arabic numerals that indicate the chords and their inversions. (Each blank should contain at least a Roman numeral, a figure, or a dash.)

Notice that the soprano and bass notes and the Roman numeral of the first chord are given and that there is a blank provided for each of the other chords in the progression.

q.s:
Assignment: Sing the pitches in accurate rhythm and with a steady tempo.

Procedure: You should use 1 minute and 15 seconds to practice and up to 30 seconds to perform the melody. You may play the starting pitch for the melody at the beginning of the practice period.

Your performance:

  • 1. You may sing note names (C-D-E), syllable names (do-re-mi), scale-degree numbers (1-2-3), or a neutral syllable (for example, ta-ta-ta).
  • 2. Even though you will hear the starting pitch of the printed melody, you may transpose the melody to a key that is comfortable.
  • 3. You should use some of the practice time to perform out loud. You may write on the music if you wish.
  • 4. You may not use any device (for example, a metronome or a musical instrument) to assist you in your practice or performance.
  • 5. You will be evaluated on rhythmic accuracy, pitch accuracy (relative to tonic), and continuity (maintaining a steady tempo). You may start over, if you need to, but there will be a deduction from your score. You will not be evaluated on the quality of your singing voice.

Look over the melody, practice the melody, and then perform the melody.

Suggested time: Play the starting pitch for the melody and then use 1 minute and 15 seconds to practice and up to 30 seconds to perform the melody.

q.s:
Assignment: Sing the pitches in accurate rhythm and with a steady tempo.

Procedure: You should use 1 minute and 15 seconds to practice and up to 30 seconds to perform the melody. You may play the starting pitch for the melody at the beginning of the practice period.

Your performance:

  • 1. You may sing note names (C-D-E), syllable names (do-re-mi), scale-degree numbers (1-2-3), or a neutral syllable (for example, ta-ta-ta).
  • 2. Even though you will hear the starting pitch of the printed melody, you may transpose the melody to a key that is comfortable.
  • 3. You should use some of the practice time to perform out loud. You may write on the music if you wish.
  • 4. You may not use any device (for example, a metronome or a musical instrument) to assist you in your practice or performance.
  • 5. You will be evaluated on rhythmic accuracy, pitch accuracy (relative to tonic), and continuity (maintaining a steady tempo). You may start over, if you need to, but there will be a deduction from your score. You will not be evaluated on the quality of your singing voice.

Look over the melody, practice the melody, and then perform the melody.

Suggested time: Play the starting pitch for the melody and then use 1 minute and 15 seconds to practice and up to 30 seconds to perform the melody.

q.s:
Complete the bass line for the melody below, following eighteenth-century voice-leading procedures. Below the bass line, write the Roman and Arabic numerals that indicate the harmonies and inversions implied by the soprano and bass. Observe the following:

A. Keep the portion you compose consistent with the first two phrases.

  • 1. Write an appropriate cadence at each phrase ending, including a perfect authentic cadence at the final cadence.
  • 2. Give melodic interest to the bass line by balancing upward and downward motion and by balancing melodic steps and leaps.
  • 3. Vary the motion of the bass line in relation to the soprano.
  • 4. Use mostly quarter notes. (Where appropriate, note values ranging from half notes to eighth notes may be used.)

B. Do not notate alto and tenor lines.

Suggested time: 20 minutes.

q.s:
Complete the bass line for the melody below, following eighteenth-century voice-leading procedures. Below the bass line, write the Roman and Arabic numerals that indicate the harmonies and inversions implied by the soprano and bass. Observe the following:

A. Keep the portion you compose consistent with the first phrase.

  • 1. Write an appropriate cadence at each phrase ending, including a perfect authentic cadence at the final cadence.
  • 2. Give melodic interest to the bass line by balancing upward and downward motion and by balancing melodic steps and leaps. (Embellishing tones are not required. If you choose to use them, the only acceptable embellishing tones are unaccented passing tones, unaccented neighbor tones, and unaccented chordal skips.)
  • 3. Vary the motion of the bass line in relation to the soprano.
  • 4. Use mostly quarter notes. (Where appropriate, note values ranging from half notes to eighth notes may be used.)

B. Do not notate alto and tenor lines.

Suggested time: 20 minutes.

q.s:
Directions: Answer questions 1-7 in the space provided. If you choose to use the facing pages of manuscript paper for scratch work, be sure to save time for writing your final answer in the staves provided directly below each question. If you need to rewrite your answer to any question, use the facing page of music manuscript paper and indicate on the page with the question that your answer is on the facing page.

Questions 12 For each of these questions, you are to notate on the staves provided the correct pitch and rhythm of a short melody that you will hear. Make sure that any accidentals you use are appropriate for the key signature provided. In each case, the pulse will be established before the first playing of the melody.

Question 1. The melody will be played three times. There will be a pause of 30 seconds after the first playing and a one-minute pause after each subsequent playing. The melody you will hear uses all four of the measures provided below and contains no rests. The melody will be played on a bassoon.

The pitch of the first note has been provided. Be sure to notate the rhythm of that note. Now listen to the melody for the first time and begin working.

 

Question 1. The melody will be played three times. There will be a pause of 30 seconds after the first playing and a one-minute pause after each subsequent playing. The melody you will hear uses all four of the measures provided below and contains no rests. The melody will be played on a bassoon.

The pitch of the first note has been provided. Be sure to notate the rhythm of that note. Now listen to the melody for the first time and begin working.

Assignment: For each of the two given melodies, sing the pitches in accurate rhythm and with a steady tempo.
 
Procedure: For each melody, you will have 1 minutes and 15 seconds to practice and 30 seconds to perform the melody. You will hear the starting pitch for each melody at the beginning of the practice period. After the end of the practice period, you will have 30 seconds to perform the melody. A recorded announcement will alert you to the end of each practice and performance period. Directions on the recording will assist you in the operating the recorder.
 
Your performance: 
a) You may sing note names (C-D-E), syllable names (do-re-mi), scale-degree numbers (1-2-3), or a neutral syllable (for example, ta-ta-ta).
b) Even though you will hear the starting pitch of the printed melody, you may transpose the melody to a key that is comfortable.
c) You should use some of the practice time to perform out loud. You may write on the music if you wish.
d) You may note use any device (for example, a metronome or a musical instrument) to assist you in your practice or performance.
e) You will be evaluated on rhythmic accuracy, pitch accuracy (relative to tonic), and continuity (maintaining a steady tempo). You may start over, if you need to, but there will be a deduction from your score. You will not be evaluated on the quality of your singing voice.
End of general directions. The proctor will now press the STOP button.

Your performance: 

a) You may sing note names (C-D-E), syllable names (do-re-mi), scale-degree numbers (1-2-3), or a neutral syllable (for example, ta-ta-ta).

b) Even though you will hear the starting pitch of the printed melody, you may transpose the melody to a key that is comfortable.

c) You should use some of the practice time to perform out loud. You may write on the music if you wish.

d) You may note use any device (for example, a metronome or a musical instrument) to assist you in your practice or performance.

e) You will be evaluated on rhythmic accuracy, pitch accuracy (relative to tonic), and continuity (maintaining a steady tempo). You may start over, if you need to, but there will be a deduction from your score. You will not be evaluated on the quality of your singing voice.

You will hear the starting pitch for the melody at the beginning of the 1 minute and 15 second practice period. After the end of the practice period, you will have 30 seconds to perform the melody. A recorded announcement will alert you to the end of each practice and performance period. Directions on the recording will assist you in operating the recorder.

Your performance:

a) You may sing note names (c-d-e), syllable names (do-re-mi), scale-degree numbers (1-2-3), or a neutral syllable (for example, ta-ta-ta).

b) Even though you will hear the starting pitch of the printed melody, you may transpose the melody to a key that is comfortable.

c) You should use some of the warm-up and practice time to perform out loud. You may write on the music if you wish.

d) You may not use any device (for example, a metronome or a musical instrument) to assist you in your practice or performance.

e) You will be evaluated on pitch accuracy (relative to tonic), rhythm, and continuity (maintaining a steady tempo). You may start over if you need to, but there will be a deduction from your score. You will not be evaluated on the quality of your singing voice.

Look over the melody and begin practicing. You have 1 minute and 15 seconds to practice. This is the starting pitch of the printed melody.
